page.title: 08Wild flowers in Blean Woods
page.content: A great many wild flowers can be seen at the edges of woodland in this area. During a walk in August, over 20 species were observed in bloom. The most prolific being the pale yellow wood cow wheat/MELAMPYRUM PRATENSE/ along the rides where selective weedkilling has taken place. This plant is eaten by the larvae of the Heath Fritillary butterfly which can be seen in June. In the clearings a large amount of Bay Willowherb was seen. Groups of acid loving plants are to be found in small areas including the Heath spotted Orchid /SIEGLINGIA DECUMBENS/, Heather and various Sedges. Recently coppiced areas provide habitat for many of the more common as well as some unusual flora.
